text: we've all seen the images of violence
and uncertainty in Ukraine and they can
sometimes get a bit confusing but now we
have some data to help sort things out
in the data shows 77% of Ukrainians want
their country to remain a unified
Ukraine that's according to a new survey
by the Pew Research Center all this data
was collected after Russia annexed
Crimea but before the recent flare-ups
in Odessa and elsewhere so yes a big
majority want Ukraine to stay as one but
that's not the whole story if we just
look at Crimea a majority there want the
right to secede language further
illustrates the situation in western
Ukraine 66 percent of people only want
Ukrainian as the official language but
in the east seventy-three percent of
people say Ukrainian and Russian should
be official languages overall most
Ukrainians don't think the Kiev
government should recognize Crimea's
vote to secede but not so in Crimea and
that's where President Putin is a pretty
popular guy a majority of crimeans have
confidence in him and as for President
Obama well
these days Putin also has a majority of
people in Russia behind him - Pew
Research further found that about six in
ten Russians think there are parts of
other countries that actually belong to
Russia but back in Russia friendly
eastern Ukraine they're still pessimism
with the Ukrainian presidential election
set for late May only 27 percent think
it will be free and fair
David Botti BBC News Washington
